obsessions our picks latest popular like us on facebook follow us on twitter about us Atlas quartz index quartz app quartz quartz India quartz Africa Change your edition back to menu HAIL MARY The Pope inspired a venture capitalist to launch a startup accelerator at the Vatican Written by Michael J. Coren May 05, 2017 How are your metrics? (Reuters / Alessandro Di Meo/pool) Share Written by Michael J. Coren May 05, 2017 The great contradiction at the heart of the Silicon Valley‚Äôs self-image is that it helps the world while becoming fabulously rich. The record, to say the least, is mixed. Facebook, Google, and Apple undoubtedly benefit millions of peoples‚Äô lives while generating enormous, unprecedented wealth (for some). Yet the human toll‚Äîlost jobs, exploited contractors, massive concentration of wealth at the expense of the lower and middle class, and shuttered newspapers and small companies‚Äîare just as real. This doesn‚Äôt touch on more unsavory practices such as a wage fixing cartel by Apple, Google and others that depressed workers‚Äô incomes, as well as outright deception by companies such as Theranos. Can companies that aim for huge profits while doing good deliver on the latter? A venture capitalist, inspired by Pope Francis‚Äô 2015 encyclical on the environment, is starting an accelerator in Rome to try. Stephen Forte, a serial entrepreneur and founder of Fresco Capital‚Ää, announced on Medium on May 4 that he is starting the Laudato Si‚Äô challenge to ‚Äúinvest in companies that are aiming for huge profits while also caring about doing good in the world.‚Äù These companies will specifically focus on climate change. For the challenge, Forte says founders will start out in a virtual program advised by mentors to hone their business models and accelerate growth. The in-person program runs from July through early September in Rome and culminates in a Demo Day at the Vatican in December (Forte does not say whether the program has an official relationship with the Vatican, and did not respond to inquires at the time of publishing). The program offers an optional $100,000 equity investment for 6%-8% equity stake in the company. Companies are expected to have a prototype and some sales or customer adoption, although not raised a large venture capital round. Climate change is the unifying theme but the ‚Äúmission-driven, for-profit startups‚Äù can work in energy, food, water, conservation, finance and other fields. Forte argues companies who want to put social missions at the center of their business cannot find enough funding. To fix this, the accelerator will back ‚Äúfor-profit mission driven companies that focus on the challenge and values of the Laudato Si,‚Äô‚Äù citing Pope Francis‚Äôs On Care for our Common Home encyclical as the ‚Äúperfect opportunity‚Ä¶to act.‚Äù Pope Francis‚Äô 80-page edict seeks to enshrine environmental stewardship of humans‚Äô common home at the heart of Catholic theology. Caring for the Earth, he argues, is inextricable from caring for each other. ‚ÄúHow wonderful would it be if the growth of scientific and technological innovation would come along with more equality and social inclusion,‚Äù the Pope said in a 2017 TED talk on the topic. ‚ÄúOnly by educating people to a true solidarity will we be able to overcome the ‚Äòculture of waste,‚Äô which doesn‚Äôt concern only food and goods but, first and foremost, the people who are cast aside by our techno-economic systems which, without even realizing it, are now putting products at their core, instead of people.‚Äù Most Popular The psychological importance of wasting time Read full story home our picks popular latest obsessions search
Navigation Menu Social Media News Social Media News Social Media Help Facebook Help Twitter Help Google+ Help LinkedIn Help Instagram Help Pinterest Help Youtube Help Technology Technology News Tech Tips Apps & Software Gadgets Tablets Apple Kindle Samsung Internet Search Engine News Web Bing Google Yahoo Business Advertising Blogging Development Start Ups Mobile Android Blackberry iPhone Reviews Windows Phone Infographics Follow us on Twitter Follow us on Facebook Subscribe To Rss Feed Follow Us On Google+ Home ¬ª Google Photos will create Mother‚Äôs Day video from your photo collection Google Photos will create Mother‚Äôs Day video from your photo collection Home ¬ª Apps & Software ¬ª Google Photos will create Mother‚Äôs Day video from your photo collection Posted By Ola Ric on May 5, 2017 | 0 comments Share the joy ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† Credit: https://thenextweb.com/apps/2017/05/05/google-can-now-whip-up-a-mothers-day-video-from-your-photo-library/#.tnw_Mq0SpmHL Mother‚Äôs Day is here again, and Google wants you to show just how much you treasure and appreciate her. So, if you don‚Äôt know how to show your appreciation, Google Photos can help you sort yourself out. With Google Photos, Google will help you out with a short video featuring your mother and maybe you or your little ones. The app will scan through your photo collection and put together a slideshow of old pictures that bring back old memories. The first thing is to have your pictures, and of course, that of your mother uploaded to Google Photos, then visit this page to create a slideshow. You will also need to identify your mother from the pictures you have uploaded‚Äîand once done, the app will take it up from there. After a while, you will be presented with a video slideshow on the Assistant screen, which can then be saved to your desktop or mobile device. You can even share a link created during the process of creating the video via your favorite social media websites. I personally fancy the idea of sharing the video link as it helps you to tell the entire world how much you love your mother. Mothers occupy a special place in our heart, and what better ways to express a token of love towards them. Maybe not enough to show appreciation for what your mother did, but it‚Äôs a lovely place to start from on the occasion of the 2017 Mother‚Äôs Day. Video Credit: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fVadhc9ml28&feature=youtu.be With Google Photos, every update moves it closer to that perfect photo app that everyone truly can‚Äôt get enough of. The last update for example, took the app a level ahead of rival apps with an automatic video stabilizing feature. The automatic video stabilizing feature added last month has the capability of automatically stabilizing videos in your camera roll with just a tap. Updating Google Photos with stabilization feature turns the app into one of the best you can get when it comes to shooting a top quality video. If you have a phone that lacks steadying anything, now you have the right app to stabilize things and help turn your shots to professional works. Google Photos also recently added a functionality that automatically corrects the white balance in any image you open. This will solve a lot of stress and make your picture look like that of a pro. It means you no longer need a third-party tool in the form of an editing tool to correct off tones. Auto white balance has already rolled out to both Android and web; but iOS users may have to wait a little longer. A few other editing tools were also added to the app, including, quick rotate, and ability to easily and quickly edit a photo on the web. Google also recently added a new feature that makes it easier to back up your photos no matter the connection. Photos just keeps getting better, and what a way to go with the latest update. So, go out there and treat your mother to an unforgettable Mother‚Äôs Day experience. news tech spaceflight science & astronomy search for life skywatching video Eclipse 2017 news tech spaceflight science & astronomy search for life skywatching video Eclipse 2017 news tech spaceflight science & astronomy search for life skywatching video Eclipse 2017 Space.com Spaceflight Google Launches Artist's 'Live' Phone Cases Inspired by Women Astronauts By Robert Z. Pearlman, collectSPACE.com Editor | May 5, 2017 01:25pm ET MORE Imagine you could press a button on your smart phone case that would immediately connect you to trailblazing astronauts who would share their experiences of seeing Earth from above. Now, thanks to director Eliza McNitt and Google, you can do just that. The emerging artist and technology company have teamed up to introduce a series of space exploration-inspired "Artworks Live Cases" for Google's Pixel phones, which at a push of a button launches "Dot of Light," a new short documentary by McNitt featuring women who made history in space. "When you get a case, you download an app and the app gives you a different wallpaper," said McNitt, describing the live cases. "There's a button on the back of the phone and when you click that, it will launch the documentary. So, the story is connected about these women who have always dreamt about this journey to the stars." ['Dot of Light' Documentary Tells Story of 3 Female Astronauts (Video)] Google and film director Eliza McNitt have launched "Dot of Light," a new short documentary and exclusive smart phone case series, as inspired by history-making women astronauts. Credit: Google McNitt, whose earlier work has focused on merging virtual reality experiences with scientific discovery and an artistic narrative ‚Äî notably, the Hubble Space Telescope-themed "A Fistful of Stars," which resulted in the largest community VR experience to date ‚Äî has dreamt of that journey, too. She drew inspiration for "Dot of Light" and for the design of the live cases from the stories told by Kathy Sullivan, the first American woman to spacewalk; Nicole Stott, the first woman to paint while in space; and Anousheh Ansari, the first woman to privately-fund her own trip into space. "I was just captivated by their experiences and that simple human connection to our planet from above," McNitt told collectSPACE in an interview. "And what it's like to look out the window of the International Space Station and just how human space travel becomes." Sullivan, who until recently served as the administrator of NOAA (National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration), logged 22 days on three flights into space, including on the mission to deploy the Hubble Space Telescope. Stott, who is now an accomplished artist herself, spent more than 100 days in Earth orbit as a space station crewmember. Ansari, whose family was the title sponsor for the original X Prize competition, became the first Iranian-American in space on her 11-day mission. In the ten-minute "Dot of Light," Ansari, Stott and Sullivan talk about how their own perspectives of space and Earth changed as a result of their vantage point from high above the planet. It was one of those stories, shared by Ansari at an earlier meeting with McNitt, which served as the theme for the entire project. "One thing that Anousheh said has always stuck in mind," said McNitt. "She was listening to her iPod and staring out the window and saw this thunderstorm below, but it looked like a light show. She thought it was so beautiful ‚Äî but it struck her how there were people below probably stuck in the chaos and yet from above, it looked like this marvelous light show." "If anything, I would say that image inspired the cases and the creation of the film because I was so drawn to that idea of space through the eyes of these astronauts," she said. Film director Eliza McNitt interviews astronaut Kathy Sullivan, the first American woman to walk in space, for McNitt's short documentary, "Dot of Light," commissioned by Google. Credit: Google The case designs, which also drew from the experiences of astronauts Eileen Collins, the first woman to command a space crew, and Mae Jemison, the first African-American woman to fly into space, feature colorful images of planets, nebulas, rocket launches and explorers. "There is a case that we did of a spacewalk and the image is of someone free-floating. Kathy's reaction ‚Äî she saw it and really loved it, but she laughed and said, 'They would have really been mad at me if I had a spacewalk without a tether!'" McNitt recalled, also laughing. Google debuted the documentary, which is free to watch on YouTube, and began sales of the live cases on Friday (May 5), the 56th anniversary of the first American human spaceflight, which is also National Space Day and National Astronaut Day. McNitt's nine case designs cost $40 each and are only available online from the Google Store in the U.S., Canada, Australia, United Kingdom and Germany. "I hope that this series reflects the accomplishments of all of these women astronauts. I think the story of the human exploration of space is a universal one and hopefully, the cases reflect a desire to venture to the stars," said McNitt. "Being able to make cases that represent that journey and then the journey beyond, to one day interstellar travel, was really exciting ‚Äî to be able to reimagine the past that we know and then the future of space exploration," she said. For more information or to purchase Eliza McNitt's "Dot of Light" Artworks Live Cases, see the Google Store at: livecase.withgoogle.com/artworks/info/elizamcnitt Watch Eliza McNitt's "Dot of Light" documentary, featuring Kathy Sullivan, Nicole Stott and Anousheh Ansari, at collectSPACE. Follow collectSPACE.com on Facebook and on Twitter at @collectSPACE. Copyright 2017 collectSPACE.com. All rights reserved. Editor's Recommendations 'Dot of Light' Documentary Tells Story of 3 Female Astronauts | Trailer Anousheh Ansari Honored with Portraits by Peter Max Record-Breaking Women in Spaceflight History Best Spaceflight and Space History Books Subscribe To SPACE.com Submit Follow Us Most Popular NASA Examines Effects of 2017 Spending Bill on Science Programs Arianespace Launches for First Time Since French Guiana Protests Ended Science Videos Wow Judges in Data-Visualization Face-Off Ancient Meteor Strike Triggered Eruptions Lasting Up to a Million Years Hubble Uses 'Super Vision' on Galaxy Cluster - STScI Astronomer Explains | Video HomeAbout Us Company Company Info About Us Contact Us Advertise with Us Using Our Content Licensing & Reprints Terms of Use Copyright Policy Privacy Policy Network Top Ten Reviews Tom's Guide Laptop Mag Tom's Hardware Business News Daily Tom's IT Pro Space.com Live Science Active Junky ShopSavvy AnandTech FOLLOW US SUBSCRIBE TO SPACE SUBMIT Copyright ¬© All Rights Reserved.
e-paper India Follow us: Today in New Delhi, India May 05, 2017-Friday -¬∞C New Delhi Humidity - Wind - select city Metro cities - Delhi Mumbai Chennai Kolkata Other cities - Noida Gurgaon Bengaluru Hyderabad Bhopal Chandigarh Dehradun Indore Jaipur Lucknow Patna Ranchi Powered by Close india world cities opinion ipl 2017 sports entertainment lifestyle business tech education whatnow photos videos jaago re Livemint Livehindustan Shine HTcampus Mycollegesabroad Desimartini Google to train AKTU faculty on Android development in‚ÄâGreater Noida Google will hold a workshop for technical colleges from‚ÄâMay 8 to May 12 noida Updated: May 06, 2017 00:00 IST Vaibhav Jha Hindustan Times All technical colleges affiliated to AKTU, earlier known as UPTU, can send their faculty for the training.(Sunil Ghosh/HT File) In support of the Union government‚Äôs Skill India initiative , Google will train the teaching faculty of technical colleges situated in Greater Noida on ‚ÄòAndroid development‚Äô in a five-day workshop called an ‚ÄòAndroid Skilling‚Äô programme. The Android Skilling programme will be organised in ITS Engineering College from May 8-12 with dozens of teachers attending it. All technical colleges affiliated to Dr Abdul Kalam Technical University (AKTU) can send their faculty for the training. The seminar is being organised by AKTU and Google in order to promote digital education, as per a memorandum of understanding signed between the two. ‚ÄúThis is our faculty training programme that we host when a university is ready to introduce a Android Development Fundamentals course in its curriculum. As a result, we are conducting this training for them,‚Äù said Peter Lubbers, senior programme manager, Google Developer Training. Google had launched a Mobile Skilling programme in 2016 to train and certify two million developers in India over three years. Under this programme, the internet giant will also offer a standalone course via several training partners, including training institutes. ‚ÄúIndia will have four million software developers by 2018, becoming the largest population of developers in the world. But today, less than 25% of these developers are trained to develop and build for the mobile platform. The majority of India‚Äôs internet user base today accesses the internet from their mobile phones and almost all the future internet users in India and many of the world‚Äôs emerging countries will be mobile-use only. There is a huge opportunity for India to become a global leader in mobile app development and we want to contribute and bridge the skills gap that exists today,‚Äù said Lubbers. ‚ÄúKeeping in mind the future of students, the university administration had decided to launch a course on Android-based application development for programmes such as computer science, information technology and masters in computers applications (CS/IT/MCA). To train our faculty, we have decided to hold such workshops in areas across UP where our affiliated colleges are situated,‚Äù said Vinay Kumar Pathak, vice chancellor, AKTU. ‚ÄúAll such colleges in Greater Noida that have computer engineering related programmes such as CS, IT and MCA have been strongly advised to send their teachers to the workshop,‚Äù he added. tags Greater Noida AKTU Android development Google skill development more from noida Noida to crack down on violation of land-use norms May 05, 2017 23:59 IST Submit tower-wise completion schedule and stick to it, Noida CEO tells Credai May 06, 2017 00:02 IST Is Your Couch Making You Cough? George Lucas is Cooler Than Star Wars Science Fiction Really Hasn‚Äôt Been Good to Women More Hands-On: The New Nintendo 2DS XL is the Coolest Handheld I Don‚Äôt Want Sony Shouldn‚Äôt Release Any PS4 Exclusives This Holiday Season Nintendo Wants Switch to Match Wii‚Äôs Sales These Are the Games You Should Be Checking Out in May More There Are Four Game of Thrones Spinoffs in the Works at HBO ‚ÄòDoctor Who‚Äô Underrated Villain of the Week: The Flood Riverdale Reveals Jason Blossom‚Äôs Killer, but That‚Äôs Not the... In the New Twin Peaks Teaser, See Everyone Again After 25 Years More Comics To Read After Seeing Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 You Need To Be Reading Marvel‚Äôs Star Wars Comics Buy This Comic! Black Bolt #1 Matt Miner Unleashes Gwar-Mageddon Upon Us All More Internet Gutter: Spells Of Magic Rule The Starry Skies With This Gift Guide For Space Lovers Include the Guardians of the Galaxy at Your Next Summer Gathering The Boba Fett Diplomatic Arrives Just in Time More Tech Google‚Äôs Project Sunroof Helps Germans Go Solar By Stephanie Mlot 05.05.2017 :: 2:15PM EDT Just enter your address to find out more (via Google) Stay on target An Old Coal Mine May Become The Largest Solar Farm In Kentucky California Briefly Met 50% Of Its Energy Needs With Solar Last Month Environmentally friendly Germans can now determine the solar potential of their rooftops. Nearly two years after launching Project Sunroof in the US, Google is expanding its program to Europe‚Äîstarting in the Land der Dichter und Denker. Using high-resolution aerial mapping, Google can help consumers ‚Äúmake accurate decisions about solar power for their homes,‚Äù Project Sunroof product manager Joel Conkling wrote in a blog announcement. Some 7 million buildings are covered, including those in urban areas like Munich, Berlin, Rhine-Main, and Ruhr, where homeowners can calculate their estimated rooftop solar potential by simply entering their address online. The smart technology‚Äîan amalgamation of Google Earth, Google Maps, 3D models, and machine learning‚Äîfactors in roof orientation, nearby tree and building shade, and local weather patterns. It also considers typical electric bill rates for customized results. My parents‚Äô house in Mount Pleasant, S.C., for example, collects 1,615 hours of usable sunlight per year (based on daily weather patterns). Combined with the 1,251 square feet available for solar panels (based on 3D modeling and nearby tree coverage), they could save $15,000 over 20 years. To refine the results, tap ‚Äúfine-tune estimate.‚Äù If you‚Äôre already convinced, click through to see solar providers in your area. German users can purchase a suitable system of photovoltaic modules, energy storage, and system management software directly from Project Sunroof partner E.ON. ‚ÄúWith Sunroof, we are able to digitize sales of solar systems more intensively and thereby increase the appeal of photovoltaics,‚Äù E.ON COO Karsten Wildberger said in a statement. ‚ÄúIt clearly demonstrates the potential benefits of digitalization for the ongoing shift in energy production.‚Äù Initially tested in the San Francisco Bay Area, Fresno, and Boston, the program, which utilizes the same technology in use by Google Earth, has expanded nationwide, and currently covers about 40 percent of German homes. There is no word on a timeline for future growth within the the country or the rest of the globe. ‚ÄúGoogle has been using renewable energy sources within our own infrastructure and beyond for many years,‚Äù Conkling wrote, highlighting the company‚Äôs commitment for 100 percent renewable energy across worldwide operations in 2017. ‚ÄúWith Project Sunroof, we want to help people become even more aware of the solar potential that‚Äôs just above the rafters,‚Äù he continued. ‚ÄúThe future is bright.‚Äù Share Facebook Twitter Linkedin Pinterest Reddit E.ON germany Google Project Sunroof solar solar panel Speak Your Mind More in Tech 05.05.2017 :: 1:30PM EDT :: Daniel Starkey Tech Google Launches New Phone Cases in Honor of Space Day! Tech 05.05.2017 :: 9:00AM EDT :: Stephanie Mlot Tech Join Team TARDIS With New ‚ÄòDoctor Who‚Äô Skype Bot Tech 05.05.2017 :: 8:00AM EDT :: Stephanie Mlot Tech MIT 3D Printing Technology Could Build Homes on the Moon Tech 05.04.2017 :: 3:45PM EDT :: Stuart Tech Simple Geek‚Äôs Guide to Blocking People Tech 05.04.2017 :: 1:30PM EDT :: Stephanie Mlot Tech ISS Design Challenge Winner 3D-Printed in Space Tech More subscribe to our newsletter: Subscribing to a newsletter indicates your consent to our Terms of Use and Privacy Policy. Google Pixel long-term review: Still the best smartphone I've ever used David Ruddock Follow View All Posts 2017/05/02 3:28pm PDTMay 2, 2017 75 Plus 1 on G+ 330 Share on Facebook 120 Share on Twitter Total Shares525 News Phone Reviews Pixel Pixel XL Article Contents 1 The hardware 2 Battery life 3 Display, audio, and wireless 4 Camera 5 Performance and software 6 Value 7 Conclusion I have been using the Google Pixel XL for six months now. Not continuously, mind you - I have taken breaks here and there. But after using the Galaxy S8+, the LG G6, and the OnePlus 3T, there is only one phone I've instinctively found myself returning to, and it's this one. Google's Pixel isn't without its flaws; in fact, it has a great many I can cite with ease. The Bluetooth connectivity sucks. The back of the phone has very obvious wear rub. The glass window scratches easily. It's not waterproof. 'OK Google' hotword detection breaks for no apparent reason, necessitating a reboot. The fingerprint scanner is slower than what you'd find on a number of competitor devices. The value proposition is mediocre at best. The screen to body ratio pales in comparison to phones like the G6 or Galaxy S8. And you can't even buy the damn thing. Why do I keep picking up the Pixel time and time again, then? Am I just a brainwashed Google fanboy (don't answer that question)? The answer is consistency. In the nearly seven years I've been doing this, I have never used an Android phone that has held up so well to the tortures of time. The Pixel XL feels nearly as smooth as the day I began using it six months ago. Android glides along with best-in-class touch latency and a responsiveness that feels immediate (if not manic) and satisfying. It's not just performance, either. My battery life remains largely predictable, too, and largely very good. The camera continues to impress with its swift launches and ease of use, and it produces the most consistently excellent results of any smartphone camera I have ever used. HDR+ is easily, for me, the best smartphone camera feature out there. Oh, and even if the fingerprint scanner is a bit slow compared to some, at least the damn thing is easy to reach and reads consistently. Is the XL worth $770 to pick up today? I don't really think so, let alone $870 for the 128GB version we all actually want. And honestly, I have a hard time seeing the point of the smaller 5" model at $650 right now, that just feels like lunacy. The XL offers better battery life and is far from "big phone" status in terms of actual usability - it's really the only one of the two that warrants consideration, in my opinion. With that, let's dive in to the details. The hardware Put the Google Pixel XL next to a Galaxy S8+ and you'll have a pretty hard time finding much to love about Google's phone. 2017 is ushering in a new era of smartphone design language and packaging, and the Pixel XL clearly hails from the period prior to that shift. To be fair, it did come out six months ago. But there's no doubt that from an industrial design point of view, the Pixel is aging fairly rapidly. The 5.5" Pixel XL is nearly as tall as a Galaxy S8+, but the latter has a 6.2" display. Line up the bottom of the S8's screen with the Pixel XL's, and it becomes apparent just how much more panel Samsung has managed to shove into a frame that is only a few millimeters taller. Granted, this does have ergonomic consequences (the S8+ is unabashedly more difficult to use one-handed than the XL because of the screen's height), but I think it's safe to say most of us want more screen where we can get it. I still think the Pixel XL is perfectly nice to hold and like the texture of the aluminum opposed to Samsung and LG's new glass-heavy designs. I also still believe the fingerprint scanner is in the ideal location, unlike the Galaxy S8, which has the most frustrating one in existence. The position of the camera makes accidental smudging less likely, too, and I really like the perfectly flush look Google was able to achieve with the glass window. Visible wear lines on the casing In terms of wear and tear, my XL has... not fared well. The finish on the Quite black model I have here has begun to very noticeably rub off in areas where the aluminum chassis is slightly more raised than others. You could remedy this with a skin, but I personally like this phone totally unadorned. Otherwise, though, it's held up well - the buttons are still fine and I don't notice any real physical problems with the phone aside from the aforementioned finish wear. Just don't drop it in the toilet. Battery life As I said in the introduction, it's consistently good. I always have a pretty clear sense of how much time I've got left when I'm really starting to push my XL to the limits of its longevity. If I'm having a Wi-Fi heavy day with lots of using the phone for browsing the web and texting, 5 hours of screen-on time is doable. If I'm away from home and largely on LTE, I can pretty reliably get 4 hours of screen time assuming it's not stretched over much longer than a 12-hour period. For a full 16-hour day away from wall outlets and going it on mobile data alone, 3 hours is what I generally end up managing. This probably won't impress many of you with Xiaomi, Huawei, or Exynos-powered Samsung devices, and I understand that. But the thing about the Pixel has been just how well I've been able to learn what I can expect in terms of battery performance based on the conditions I'm using it in. I know I can throw in a bit of tethering and Bluetooth streaming without completely obliterating the battery, for example, if I'm at 60% halfway through my day and won't top up till later that evening. My range anxiety with the Pixel is exceptionally low, even if it doesn't offer the very best battery life of any smartphone. Would I like the next-generation Pixels to have larger batteries? Yes, please. Relying only on software to ensure a good power consumption experience is missing half the equation (and I'm not saying that's what Google did). Stuffing even a few-hundred more milliamp hours of capacity in there can be the difference between a dead phone and one that gets you back to the charger at the end of the night. Always fit a bigger battery when you can. Display, audio, and wireless The Super AMOLED Quad HD display still looks bright and crisp, even if the new panel on the S8 is clearly a cut above the part Google is using on the Pixel. Even so, I think the screen is one area where the Pixel XL earns its $770 keep, as there really aren't many phones out there you're going to find which are considerably better in this regard unless they have "Galaxy" inscribed on the back. On the audio front, I found the Pixel's bottom-firing speaker mediocre at the time I reviewed it, and I find it mediocre today. Sadly, it's not getting much in the way of competition, either - both the G6 and S8 have speakers that are at least as unimpressive, if not worse in certain respects, and I hope Google can at least give us that quasi-BoomSound using the earpiece speaker on the Pixel 2 this year. The headphone jack offers performance in line with most Snapdragon 820-series devices and thus isn't the best candidate for pushing your high-impedance cans, but I find it perfectly serviceable in the gym even at high outputs. The quality is there, even if this generation of Qualcomm parts didn't offer as much power as audiophiles probably would have liked. One of my biggest gripes about the XL is its Bluetooth performance. I have used three separate Pixel XLs, and all of them have absolutely terrible Bluetooth signal. Even think about touching the phone in the wrong spot, and the music stream to your headphones or car will cut out. It is absolutely obnoxious. It doesn't matter what kind of headphones, speaker, or car A/V unit - it sucks with anything I've tried. Even walking around with the Pixel XL in my pocket connected to a pair of Bluetooth headphones results in cuts every single time I step up a stair or rest my hand against the pocket the phone is in. The 7.1.2 patch has done nothing to alleviate this issue. It's borderline embarrassing: I have had the Pixel XL corrupt the Bluetooth profiles on my car three times. Each time, the only solution was to factory reset the infotainment unit. I had to factory reset my car. No other phone has ever done this to me, though since the 7.1.2 update this hasn't happened - yet. Wi-Fi performance, on the other hand, has been quite excellent for me, and LTE signal is at least as good as most other phones I tested in 2016. Now that I'm on Verizon, I'm even getting some HD voice calls, which is such a huge upgrade in terms of the call experience. But seriously, Google: get the damn Bluetooth right next time. Camera I can't stop taking pictures with the Pixel. I love this camera. No more words: just photos. ¬† ¬† Performance and software Aside from the aforementioned Bluetooth problems, you know what I find so wonderful about the Pixel? I rarely really get annoyed using it. Apps load up at consistently quick speeds, the OS always feels snappy and responsive, and the touch latency is positively iPhone-y. Like your finger is truly controlling the elements on the screen. The home button and back key respond lightning-quick, in a way that almost starts to make them feel like real buttons. I struggle to really convey how right Google got the basic "interacting with the phone" stuff here. What they managed to do with the Pixel will only make the Pixel 2 that much better a phone, and I will be clear: I do not feel this way about the Galaxy S8. The Pixel feels incredibly natural and pleasant to interact with. There are still hiccups, delays, and little areas where things just don't feel as smooth and seamless as they should on the S8. Google nailed this. No other phone I've used has. Is the Pixel as fast in a straight-line speed sense as a OnePlus 3T? No. But counting fractional differences between the number of seconds it takes to load an app or how long before it's pushed out of memory are not methods that convey an experience. They tell you a couple of very specific things under a controlled circumstance. In practice, I simply find the Pixel the most consistent and smooth Android smartphone I've ever used. But, it does have some usability issues. For one, my 'OK Google' hotword detection breaks basically once a week, necessitating a reboot. I use this when in the car, and so it's very, very inconvenient when this happens. Rebooting the phone takes a good minute-plus, and then it has to reconnect to my Bluetooth (which is never guaranteed to work). This is probably something to do with the Google app, but it's annoying nonetheless. Other than that? I struggle to find anything about the software that I really dislike. Most of my frustrations come down to third-party apps, not the Pixel. And those are annoying on any phone I use. Value When it debuted in October, the Google Pixel XL cost $770. The one you and I actually want, the 128GB model, cost $870. Six months later, the Pixel XL still costs $870. Is it worth it? Hah. No. The successor devices to the current Pixel family will be unveiled in the next five or six months. There is absolutely no good reason to shell out what, with tax, amounts to nearly a thousand dollars for this smartphone. You will absolutely regret it the moment Google announces the Pixel 2 - I guarantee you. Do not buy a Pixel right now. In fact, I'd say just don't buy a Pixel period anymore, we're just too close to the next iteration for that to be remotely sane advice. Conclusion So, that's weird, right? I can't even recommend that you buy what is easily my favorite Android smartphone currently on the market? What kind of long-term endorsement is that? That's because for all its problems and limited availability, the last six months I've used the Pixel have utterly proven to me that Google is capable of building a smartphone that, from a user experience standpoint, rises above the competition. Google's unmatched ability to optimize the way Android and the underlying phone parts interact is very much a reason I love this phone so much. A smartphone should get out of its own way when you use it - it should be an effortless canvas upon which your fingers and eyes naturally engage and interact. That means it should be fast. It should be consistent. And it should just feel right to use. I know that some of these things don't really translate well into concrete assessments, but there's something about the Pixel that really just works for me so well. It's as close to my ideal smartphone as I've ever been. I'm hoping that Google smoothes over some of the rough edges not just with the phone, but with the whole experience of buying and owning it. Why is is to hard to buy a Pixel? It's positively ridiculous just how bad Google has been at keeping this phone in stock. I also think it's hard to ignore that in 2017, the Pixel's design language and overall look and feel are clearly behind the competition. This looks like yesterday's smartphone, and even on the day it was announced it was kind of hard to really fall in love with in an aesthetic sense. At best, it's just kind of boring. Post-purchase experiences should improve, too. Google's online and live chat support are very-just-OK, and what I've heard of the RMA process hasn't been super reassuring - full price credit card holds and iffy-quality refurbished replacements. Of course, that's what happens when you're in the online-only phone sales business. Still, Google should be working to streamline defect, warranty, and accidental damage claims in a way that makes it feel like the nearly-thousand dollars you spent on your phone is going into supporting a thousands-dollar-phone experience. They really also need to stop making crappy cases that are obscenely overpriced. Google made a great phone when it built the Pixel. Now Google needs to be a great phone company. I'm curious to see if they can pull it off. Tags google pixel long term review google pixel review pixel long term review pixel xl long term review subscribe ... Dean L I got used to my S8+ fingerprint scanner after about a week. I absolutely love the position now, and never touch the camera anymore. Carson Saldanha Throw in free banana splits and you've got a deal! ;) Rickinbsb pick 2 Felonious Monk ‚úì·µõ·µâ ≥·∂¶·∂†·∂¶·µâ·µà "My 6P is losing longevity and running super slow these days." I see people say all the time that it's Samsung phones that always get slow over time. Intellectually dishonest people, I guess. sweenish They can both be right, you know. Felonious Monk ‚úì·µõ·µâ ≥·∂¶·∂†·∂¶·µâ·µà Yes, I believe they're both right, depending on various factors. My Note 4 is running better than it did with Lollipop, and a little slower than it did with KitKat. It probably has at least something to do with the Android version and what apps you install on it. My point was that it's intellectually dishonest to pretend it's a Samsung problem, as if it's unique to those phones. And that's how the people frame the problem. sweenish And you were just framing it as "not us, but them." Not better. If I misread your intent, I apologize. Felonious Monk ‚úì·µõ·µâ ≥·∂¶·∂†·∂¶·µâ·µà You did misread my intent. No problem, though. Treeburgerface It's Android that's the problem. Some Android phones get slower than others. Some Android phones lag more than others. But eventually they ALL get slower and they ALL lag. I've heard 1000 people swear that Android is "silky smooth" and "fixed" now over and over again, before "project butter" and long after and it's still not true. It's certainly improved, which you should expect with the 3 Ghz 12 core processors and 8 GB of RAM they are packing in them now, but at this point I kind of doubt Android is ever going to be quite as flawless in the GUI department as other OS's which were designed to prioritize touch input and treat the users finger like God they way they should and which prioritize reliability over ultimate capability. Just depends which set of sacrifices you are more comfortable with. Ismail Akram Well that totally sum up a perfect phone for me :) Just add Powerful AMP in that Ghisy This, times a million! What does something being overpriced mean to you? whispy_snippet I guess I should rephrase. It's not over priced when compared to what it's competing with. "Over priced" is a bit of a relative term. It doesn't hold a lot of meaning. What is over priced to one person might be a steal for another. I think you can make the argument that compared to other phones the Pixel, iPhone and Galaxy S8 are all expensive. But over priced? That's a murkier discussion. Knowledgeborn Allah I agree, but I think status plays a role in pricing when it comes to other manufacturers. Samsung and Apple both have established brands, and people are willing to pay top dollar for their devices because they've already proven themselves. Google isn't in this same position in the smartphone hardware department. Also, I'd say that both lines - e.g. Galaxy S series and iPhone - offer much more in the way of unique features and premium hardware than what Google offers with the Pixel. But that's just my personal perspective... whispy_snippet See that's where I'm not so sure. The Pixel still has the best camera of any smartphone and an amazing display to back it up. Straight away it's hit two areas out of the park that matter to most people. At launch it had a class leading SoC that continues to offer great performance. It has plenty of RAM. Rock solid build quality. A super fast and accurate fingerprint sensor. USB-C (remember the GS7 didn't which was Samsung's 2017 flagship) with fast-charging and excellent battery life. It has the most capable voice assistant. It's got the latest version of Android and what I believe to be the best overall user experience for most people - it's consistently fast and smooth, unlike anything from Samsung, and will receive timely updates for much longer than the competition. The Pixel is the iPhone of the Android world and I think it has a market to fill. Do I think the Pixel 2 needs to be better? You bet. No one is denying this. What phone doesn't need to be better than its predecessor? If the Pixel 2 doesn't at least have waterproofing and a higher display-to-bezel ratio critics will hold them to account. But I'm pretty sure these features are a guarantee. The thing is, and I've said this elsewhere, I don't really consider a lot of the hardware bells and whistles we see from the likes of Samsung all that meaningful. The curved display is a gimmick. It looks great, but I'm not at all sold from a functional perspective. The same with the new 18:9 ratio. For a mobile device I consider one handed usability important. Reaching the notification pull-down with one hand is already a no-go on the GS8 and its fingerprint sensor is another ergonomic mis-step. And a heart rate sensor? Who on earth uses this? Same goes with its iris-scanner and face recognition. Why use these options when a well positioned fingerprint sensor is more convenient? It's all just guff. Bullet points for carrier salespeople to sing about in store. I think waterproofing is a biggie though. Google can't drop the ball here. I also think wireless charging is going to become significant if Apple introduces it to their new iPhone. We've seen Google offer wireless charging in the past and then take it away because, well, I don't think that many people really cared. But I sense the tide is going to turn on this. Google's phone is priced the same as the iPhone and Galaxy S because it's being positioned as a premium product. I hate the word "premium". It's huge BS when you really think about it. But ultimately this is the strategy Google is taking with its new phone. A high margin, high performing, premium flagship for the masses. I think the best of the Pixel line is yet to come. Knowledgeborn Allah I also think the Pixel launched with a lot of good qualities and features, and that's why I rushed to purchase it. However, around the same time, I bought an iPhone 7+, just to give iOS a fair shot. Now that I've used both devices, I think it's a huge mistake to call the Pixel "the iPhone of the Android world". In reality, it doesn't even come close, and that's where the problem comes in. The iPhone is Apple's primary device when it comes to sales, but it can almost be seen as an accessory to other Apple devices, like the Mac and the iPad, etc. The Apple ecosystem allows all their devices to work together seamlessly through Continuity, and this is something Android can't replicate (at least not at this point in time). The Pixel may look similar to an iPhone, but it definitely doesn't function like one. And yes, I know that Samsung (and carriers) puts a bunch of bloat on their devices, showing off features that many people will never use. The difference, though, is all about opportunity and selection. Samsung built an entire brand around giving their consumers more than they'll ever ask for, and that's what keeps those customers coming back. I don't know anybody who uses that heart-rate sensor on the back. When I see it, I think, "Why wouldn't they remove that and use the idea of the heart-rate monitor to sell more Galaxy Gear smartwatches?" I just didn't get it... But, hypothetically, if somebody ever ends up in a situation where they need a heart-rate monitor, Samsung has them covered. I learned that firsthand when my nephew was taken to his school nurse due to an asthma attack, and the nurse didn't have a heart-rate monitor in her office. Her assistant pulled out his Galaxy S7 Edge and used the heart-rate monitor on there to relay it to medical services when they arrived. I know, that would be a generally rare occurrence, but it happens from time to time, enough for people to consider what would happen if they didn't have it. Personally, I don't think Google has enough "skin in the game" at this point to really charge that much for the Pixel. Apple and Samsung have proven brands in the smartphone space. Tech reviewers giving it high marks isn't going to matter too much among average consumers, because most people just aren't interested in technology to that extent. They just want something that works, and works reliably. Google hasn't demonstrated the ability to make hardware that just works reliably (unless you count the Chromebook Pixel line, which most people didn't buy either). It's always better to start at the bottom and work your way up, than to start at the top and get knocked all the way down. Jarrett Lennon Kaufman Because your point has NOTHING to do with the Pixel, and EVERYTHING to do with Android as a whole. Just because the Pixel doesn't stack up doesn't mean that it shouldn't be compared. Jarrett Lennon Kaufman Android, as a whole, is designed to compete with the iPhone. While the Pixel has to compete with both the iPhone AND all of Android. "Just because the Pixel doesn't stack up doesn't mean that it shouldn't be compared." You're not reading or comprehending my words if THAT was your takeaway from what I said. Not bothering anymore. Knowledgeborn Allah Android as a whole? Android is an operating system. Its rival is iOS. You're positioning the platform as if it's completely one-sided. The iPhone has to compete with various Android devices too. It just happens to have an ecosystem of hardware to aid it along the way. You're acting like an Android OEM can't do the same thing if they put in time and resources. Based on the fact that Android manufacturers are only pushing out hardware components for smartphones (and occasionally tablets and smartwatches), I'd say their biggest competitors are other Android OEMs, not Apple and iOS. For the record, the LG G6 wasn't designed to compete with the iPhone. It's competing with the Galaxy S8. The HTC 10 was competing with the G5 and S7. It's never been an Android vs "Apple ecosystem" thing on the manufacturing level. The only OEMs who actively try to compete with the iPhone are Samsung (S and Note lines) and Google (Pixel line), and it looks like Huawei is just starting to build up their consumer base in the West to do that too. The others are generally competing against other Android OEMs. Jarrett Lennon Kaufman Your first paragraph made my entire point for me: Android manufacturers', including Google, biggest competitors are one another, *not* Apple and iOS. But ANDROID's biggest competitor is iOS, which has only ONE device line: the iPhone. The Google Pixel, while it may have been designed as Google's attempt to battle the iPhone, doesn't exist in a vacuum. It's still ALSO doing everything from the first paragraph: competing against all other Android manufacturers. No matter how much Google may *want* to break out of that, their wants are irrelevant to reality. And the reality is that the Pixel is one of many Android phones, all of whom are competing against one another, the sea of which is competing against the iPhone. So how well the Pixel stacks up against the iPhone isn't relevant, as it's not the focus of this article or the reasons for David's position. WITHIN the Android ecosystem, it's simultaneously the best Android phone he's ever used (same here) and not a good idea to buy it right now BECAUSE OF THE REST OF ANDROID and NOT for any reason having anything to do with the iPhone. For anyone who wants to buy an iPhone, which is a massive number of people, there is absolutely no competition, allowing them to charge anything they want. For anyone who wants Android, there's an endless sea of competition, making the Pixel's price and specs within the refresh cycle a much harder sell right now. Felonious Monk ‚úì·µõ·µâ ≥·∂¶·∂†·∂¶·µâ·µà The headline is, "Google Pixel long-term review: Still the best smartphone I've ever used" not the best Android phone. I assume he meant Android phone, though. Still all smartphones compete with one another. And if the Note 8 is disappointing, I'll definitely consider getting an iPhone 8. Because the best smartphone (for what I want and need) is what matters to me, not the best Android phone or even the best (insert OEM here) phone. Jarrett Lennon Kaufman Cool. We have different priorities, which is fine. I couldn't use an iPhone. Apple products and their ecosystem don't fit my needs. So I'm looking at *only* Android phones. I'm still too embedded in Google's ecosystem in ways that don't make switching feasible. Knowledgeborn Allah I get your point... I still think there are certain ways around that, especially considering Google's vast amount of resources. But yes, I see how that could definitely be a problem. They could still salvage the Pixel line, though, by providing standout features like Samsung does, or by undercutting their competition with their pricing like OnePlus does. I think either of those could work fairly well. The notion of putting standout features in their devices could be a challenge, since their devices pretty much serve as a template for Android as a whole. Undercutting the competition would be easier, and that's what Google actually did for years with the Nexus program. I think that's the big "bust" factor for them. If the Pixel could be purchased for $450-500, it would still be a good purchase even now, just like the OnePlus 3T. But it's really hard to justify paying $800 for the Pixel while the Galaxy S8 and G6 are on the scene. Jarrett Lennon Kaufman They already went for standout features. They made a big push to be more "opinionated" with several software and UI customizations, along with their big hardware push. The difference is a huge number of the Galaxy standout features just aren't that compelling. That's the sort of stuff they skipped. Knowledgeborn Allah When I mentioned standout features, I was talking about exclusive ones. The Pixel doesn't really have any. They marketed the phone as having the "best camera on a smartphone", and that's turned out to be a debatable subject among people depending on their perspectives - whether they like realistic colors or oversaturated photos. The Google Assistant is now available on pretty much every Android phone, just like the fingerprint scanner gestures. The hardware from the front looks strikingly similar to the iPhone -which isn't necessarily a bad thing, but it leads people to question why they should get an iPhone lookalike, when they can get the real iPhone for the same price. The display is decent, but it's not even as good as the one on the Galaxy S7. Google ditched stereo speakers for a mediocre mono speaker. Pixel Imprint is noticeably slower than the fingerprint sensors on many cheaper offerings. The Pixel launcher was all the rage, until pretty much every third-party launcher started adding many of its features into their custom launchers. To make matters worse, the device is almost always completely out of stock online and unavailable to purchase through carriers. And those are just basic factors. Add to it the fact that Google just published an EOL report for the Pixel, solidifying the point that it'll stop getting Android OS updates in less than 2 years from now, and people are going to say, "F**k that!" That's why, personally, I think they should drop the price and salvage what's left, unless they really don't care about selling them. whispy_snippet Price and value are not intrinsically linked with "premium" products. You don't just drop the price on a product you're trying to position as high end because it's gotten a little older. You're only going to tarnish its reputation. A major reason why many people buy high end premium products is BECAUSE they're expensive. Marketing 101 mate. Phones are modern day status symbols. I remember when the Pixel launched some people scoffed at the price and said "well I'm just gonna wait for Google to discount it in a few months". I tried to tell these people that it wasn't going to happen and that the best "bang for buck" time to buy the Pixel was actually launch day. And here we are, months later, and the Pixel is still being positioned as a high end premium product. And believe me, it'll still be priced at the high end right up until the Pixel 2 launches. Apple have long been the masters of pricing their products at the high end of the market despite cheaper alternative offering features that savvy buyers demand. But look how well Apple has done. Billions of dollars in the bank thanks to sales in a product often considered a step behind the cutting edge. If you want a cheaper phone with certain features important to you, get one. There are countless options. But give up on the idea of a cheap, affordable Pixel. It's NEVER going to happen. Knowledgeborn Allah I'm not disputing that. You're correct in saying that many people buy high end products because high prices give the illusion of inherent quality. The problem, however, is that the Pixel is competing against the iPhone, and it hasn't worked. In fact, it can't and won't work. There aren't any Android OEMs who can realistically compete with Apple. They may design devices that compete with the iPhone, but they can't compete with Apple. Why? For starters, continuity. When you buy a Pixel device, you're buying a product. When you buy an iPhone, you're buying into the Apple brand and ecosystem, where all their devices, ranging from the Apple Watch to the Mac to the iPad, iPod Touch and Apple TV, and even AirPods and Beats wireless headphones, all work seamlessly together. Secondly, you're buying into the Apple Store and it's customer service benefits. Thirdly, you're buying into Apple's update cycles, which come directly from Apple to all their devices instantaneously and average around 4-5 years of support. The list goes on and on. Google isn't naive. They have their own ecosystem, but it's centered around their software and services, which you can get on practically any device. They don't have a hardware ecosystem. They knew what they were getting into, and they took a chance by trying to compete directly with the iPhone in pricing. They also see that it's clearly not working, so it's time for them to adopt a new strategy. If they actually want large groups of people buying their devices, which I'm not entirely sure they do, they either need to have standout features like Samsung Galaxy devices (which they don't), or they need to lower their prices. Right now, lowering the price on the Pixel is the only way they can salvage it. whispy_snippet I disagree on many levels. You don't establish yourself as a hardware company overnight, and you don't establish a product's premium reputation overnight. Yes, Google doesn't have the same hardware ecosystem Apple has at this stage. But they've now got skin in the game that matters most - phones. All of the products you listed from Apple don't come close to the significance of the phone. Many will never own an Apple TV, a MacBook, or Airpods. But almost everyone owns a phone - and we don't know where hardware is going to take us next. Maybe in a few years time tablets will be dead, everyone will be using hybrids and home assistants will be one of the most important gadgets in our lives. Who knows? The point is just because Google doesn't have the same suite of products as Apple doesn't mean they won't one day, or that they won't be the company that leads the pack in the hardware that matters tomorrow. Further to this, just because the Pixel lives in an ecosystem different to the iPhone doesn't mean it can't be a success in its own right. Google is known for its class leading services. What happens if it starts gradually making these hugely important and much loved services - like Google Maps, Google Drive, YouTube, Google Photos... even Google Search - Pixel exclusives? It sounds improbable - almost impossible! But it serves as a reminder of how powerful and influential Google is in the services EVERYONE uses, Apple customers included. Google entered the hottest fight in consumer tech and delivered a hugely impressive smartphone on its first attempt. It wasn't perfect, but it bettered the competition in a number of important ways. Who knows what Google has in store for the Pixel 2, 3 or 4? They're in this for the long haul. You can't expect the Pixel to sell like the iPhone and Galaxy S in its first, second or perhaps even third iteration. But as time goes by, the Pixel will stand shoulder to shoulder with Apple and Samsung's best in the minds of the average consumer. There's too much at stake for Google to sit this one out. Knowledgeborn Allah I think you're missing my point... I'm not saying Pixel can't be a success. It definitely can be, but Google needs a better strategy to make that happen. When you're competing against a company that has a structured, proven hardware ecosystem that seemingly locks users in, you have to do something extraordinary to break them out. Samsung is doing that by releasing groundbreaking smartphones. OnePlus is doing that by undercutting flagship devices via pricing. What's Google doing? The idea that Google has leverage because of their services is naive at best. Google isn't going to make their services exclusive to the Pixel or its brand because they make too much money from their portals. If they restricted YouTube to the Pixel, everybody would switch to Vimeo or something else, and Google's stock would plummet. The same goes for pretty much all their other services too. The only leverage they have is in financing, and that's very comparable to Apple anyway. In fact, I think Apple may actually be worth MORE than Google at the moment. In reality, Google will never try to conquer the hardware space. Services are their moneymaker, and the more devices they can attach their web services to, the better it is for their bottom line. That's what it's really about, at the end of the day: money. The Nexus program was more popular than the Pixel, even though there was far less advertising for it, because Google implemented a strategy of undercutting their competition. They probably thought that meant people just loved their devices and decided to launch a "premium" product. In reality, one of the main selling points of the Nexus line was its affordability. The Pixel doesn't have that, and that's why it's not selling. Again, they need to undercut their competition in pricing, or they need to implement standout features that are exclusive to the Pixel. I see those as the only sure ways to salvage the disaster that is the Pixel line right now. whispy_snippet Maybe grab yourself a cup of tea... ‚ÄúI think you're missing my point... Jarrett Lennon Kaufman A few thoughts/counters, in both directions, from my own experience: 1. I have had NONE of these Bluetooth problems you described with any device, including several different headsets as well as my car. I can travel notable distances from it, work out with it, and no disconnects. BUT, I have a Pixel, not an XL. Could that somehow be a factor? 2. Warranty service, for me, was exemplary. Yes, there was a credit card hold, but I'm used to that for advance exchanges. Otherwise it was a 10-minute process via chat, the replacement arrived in two days and was flawless, and thanks to the overall Pixel backup/restore process, the transition was painless. Easiest warranty exchange ever. Also, she allowed me to decide, on my own, to skip going through a factory reset as we both felt I'd done enough of my own troubleshooting. 3. Now the bad one: my Pixel freezes on me semi-regularly. On the one I replaced it was sometimes several times a day, but on the replacement, after about two weeks of use, it's as much as once a day, as infrequently as once every two days. Full-on hard freeze necessitating holding the power button until it reboots. NOT good. Never had this happen before or anything like it on a previous phone. Clearly, if it survived the warranty replacement, it's an app causing it. But how can an app consistently freeze up the entire system to this degree? What's not preventing that? And why is there no easy way to troubleshoot that? This is really bugging me and is the only thing damaging what's an otherwise stunning, stellar phone that's my favorite of all time. Only other disappointment for me is not having an XL which is what I wanted at launch, but the store approved me for just under enough money to get a 128GB XL. I had to choose between 32GB XL or 128GB non, and 128GB was (and still is) more important to me. But I'd rather have the better battery life and higher-res screen for VR. Still, all-in-all, and especially if I can resolve the freezing issue, this is the best phone imaginable, and its limitations are nothing compared to its heights. But yeah... at this point, wait for the next one if you're buying a phone now. Ismail Akram I have bluetooth issues he mentioned and I use Airpods with my Pixel XL.. so I thought its Airpods problem with Android(cuz I rarely use that with iPhone) About freezing it happened to me when I was on beta but after beta I don't remember freezing on Pixel XL ( but it was annoying in the start and I was so dishearted ) I recently had to sell either iPhone 7+ or Pixel XL (so I can buy S8+) and I sold iPhone 7+ :-p cuz iPhone is so easy to get Niall Murray I have the same freezing problem. Often my phone will unknowingly reboot in my pocket too. gizak No BT issues here either and I use BT in my car and headphones daily. As for your freezing, I experienced this too... after some extensive google searching, I narrowed it down to an app or two causing it. Mainly, any older app that uses your GPS periodically to poll for your location. Check apps that use GPS and haven't been updated since the latest version of Android, they may still be accessing the GPS directly instead of asking the android system for location (the newer more efficient way). Wendy By "latest version of Android", do you mean any app that hasn't been updated to Android 7+ software? My phone has been freezing every few days or so, so I'd like to try this suggestion. Felonious Monk ‚úì·µõ·µâ ≥·∂¶·∂†·∂¶·µâ·µà Are you talking about the Pixel? I'm curious if these apps freeze other phones with Nougat. Felonious Monk ‚úì·µõ·µâ ≥·∂¶·∂†·∂¶·µâ·µà Wouldn't this mean that every other phone running Nougat would freeze up when running these apps? Have you heard of anything like that? gizak Hmm, ya, you would think so. I'm not a code monkey, so this was just a hunch. The forums I came across linked it back to a family locator app causing the freezes and mentioned GPS access as the culprit. For me though, it was the WebMD allergy app that periodically polled my location to provide pollen count that froze my Pixel up daily. When I uninstalled it, my freezes seemed to go away. Wendy I'm getting the freezing error as well. I've requested for a replacement, so I'm hoping that will solve the issue. It's been freezing every so few days or so, not as frequent as yours. motoridersd The only odd Bluetooth issues I have had with this phone are related to it turning off randomly, and it has only done it a handful at times since I got it 6 months ago. I can put the phone in a drawer, walk into another room at the other end of my house, and I get no audio dropouts. Works perfectly fine in the car too. The only time I've had annoying dropouts has been in crowded airport terminals where there are a ton of competing 2.4 Ghz signals interfering and I have the phone in my pocket on the opposite side of the receiving circuitry of my BlueBuds X. Even then, it's a quick blip and it returns. Bluetooth IS much worse with The Dash, but that thing has its own issues and it happens with any other Bluetooth device I use. Maybe the BlueBuds X just have great performance that make up for the Pixel's shortcomings. Jordan I have the regular Pixel 32GB on Verizon. I have had absolutely none of the issues you describe, though Bluetooth is weak, in that if myself or my dog are in the direct line of sight between the device the speakers/headphones, it will cut out. But I have had no issues with the bluetooth in my infotainment in my car (my S6 & S7 did make me reset it a few times, however). Other than the locked bootloader (-_-) it is the perfect device! whispy_snippet A friend asked me the other day whether he should get a Pixel. I said yes. Most "normal" people don't want to wait around for months to see what the next processor is, or whether the screen on the next generation of phones has a slightly better display to bezel ratio, or whether the fingerprint scanner is going to be on the front or back. They just want something that has all the apps they use and works well. The Galaxy S8 has more hardware bells and whistles than the Pixel, but if history is any indication, the Pixel is going to be much nicer to use over the life of both devices. And ultimately, user experience trumps everything if you ask me. Especially for the non-techie. King_Android And it's a good thing they don't read the AP site either. David is speaking to his audience i.e. us nerds, not normal every day consumers. disastrousrainbow Exactly this. Having worked at Verizon for many years, giving Joe Consumer the tech enthusiast viewpoint on why they shouldn't go with a phone that's a few months away from being replaced rarely worked. More so if they were replacing a damaged or lost phone. In a situation like that, I would wholeheartedly recommend the Pixel over any other phone right now point blank dot com. Even with the S8 out. Of course, this would only be the case if they said they wanted, say, the best camera around. Or wanted a reliable software experience, etc. Those keywords would instantly bring the Pixel to mind, and I wouldn't feel bad about sending them off with one because 9 out of 10 times when the next model comes out, they will really not care, especially if their phone is still working well. When it comes to your every day man, it's not the tech enthusiast you should be listening to when recommending something, but rather the needs of the person you're trying to help. Many buyers enter the market for a new phone, because they need one. If you're one of those people who only updates their device when the current one is on its last leg, then the Pixel is an outstanding option (six months isn't something many would care to wait). The casual buyer primarily needs a good experience, preferably over a long term, and as discussed in this article, the Pixel delivers this quite well, 'right now' (to be fair, that's *if* you can find one). If the price drops once the Pixel 2 launches, even better. If you're talking to enthusiasts, then we can push this a few ways, but we always have the option to sell the Pixel, should we desire the new shiny thing. The Nexus 6P (still a great phone) fetches nice prices in the aftermarket, and the Pixel is generally understood to be an even better phone. I'm sure the Pixel will command a fine (but lower than new) aftermarket price, and there will always be a set of buyers who can't afford the absolute latest, but will be willing to scoop one up at a more realistic discount. So unless the device is missing game-breaking, hard features you rely on (waterproofing, because you're a part-time lifeguard), then I think it would be acceptable to recommend it. Home About The RealtyBizNews Team Contacts Advertise with Us Contributing Writers RealtyBizNews: Real Estate News With the latest on mortgages, refinancing, real estate & home tips Realtors US Real Estate Commercial Featured News Technology Investing Memphis Real Estate International Press Release You are here: Home / Technology / Google / Beware of ‚Äòphishing‚Äô email attacks via Google Docs Beware of ‚Äòphishing‚Äô email attacks via Google Docs May 5, 2017 by Mike Wheatley Leave a Comment Subscribe to our RSS feed to get the latest realty news. You can get our headlines via email as well, or follow us on Twitter. Hackers have developed a new scam involving Google Docs that was widely reported this week. The attackers send out emails containing a fake link to Google Docs, purportedly from one of your contacts. On the surface, the document doesn‚Äôt appear to be suspicious but anyone who clicks on it could see their Gmail account hacked. Once the link is clicked on, users will be directed to what looks like a Google login screen, TechSpot reports. But, the scammers are able to gain access to users‚Äô personal information when they click on that link as it grants permission to Google Docs to ‚Äúread, send, delete and manage your email‚Äù, and also managed your contacts. Even worse is that the link directs users to a genuine Google login page, so there‚Äôs no weird URL to give away the fact it‚Äôs a scam. There are some ways to tell though. USA Today displayed an example of an email between a bogus Google Docs invitation versus a real one. The blue logo and the words are slightly different. For instance, the real Google Docs invites you to ‚Äúedit‚Äù a document and will use the blue Google Docs logo next to the doc name. However, the scam email doesn‚Äôt include the name of the document or use the Google Docs logo. Google said it‚Äôs already disabled accounts associated with the attacks and removed the fake login pages, in order to counter the attack. If you think you‚Äôve already been duped by the scam, Google recommends going to your ‚ÄúConnected Apps and Sites‚Äù settings and revoking privileges from the Google Docs app. Also, be cautious of any emails that ask to share a Google document, even if it appears from a trusted contact. Check with the sender first to make sure it‚Äôs legitimate. The New York Times offers more tips on what to do if you think you‚Äôve clicked on such an email. These so-called phising scams are rapidly becoming more common. Last year, the Federal Trade Commission and the National Association of REALTORS issued a warning to customers about a mortgage closing phishing scam that dupes buyers into depositing their down payment into a fraudulent account. The scam hacks into real estate professionals‚Äô email accounts and targets their customers with misleading information. About Mike Wheatley Mike Wheatley is the senior editor at Realty Biz News. Got a real estate related news article you wish to share, contact Mike at mike@realtybiznews.com. Top News U.S. News World News Voices Entertainment Movies Music TV Odd News Defense Energy Sports Fantasy Football NFL NBA MLB NHL Golf Tennis College Football College Basketball Science Health Photos Latest Photos 2016 Olympics News Entertainment Sports Features Archives Archive The Almanac Search Home / Health News Web-surfing parents have less trust in pediatrician By Amy Norton, HealthDay News ¬†¬†|¬†¬† May 5, 2017 at 2:26 PM Follow @upi Comments FRIDAY, May 5, 2017 -- Health information gleaned online can alter parents' views on the advice they get from a pediatrician, a small study finds. These days, it's almost a guarantee that when kids develop a rash, fever or other worrisome symptom, parents will turn to Google, noted Dr. Ruth Milanaik, the lead researcher on the new study. Based on her team's findings, that web search may affect parents' trust in their pediatrician -- which is a concern. "Google is a fantastic tool, but it's not a doctor," Milanaik said. She's a pediatrician and associate professor at Hofstra Northwell School of Medicine, in Hempstead, N.Y. The study presented nearly 1,400 parents with a vignette of a child who'd had a rash and worsening fever for three days. The parents had at least one child, and the parents' average age was 34. The parents were split into three groups. One group was then given online information describing symptoms of scarlet fever, while a second group viewed information on select symptoms of Kawasaki disease. A third group of parents -- the "control" group -- saw no online information. All of the parents were told that a doctor had diagnosed the child with scarlet fever. In general, the study found, parents who viewed information on scarlet fever were more likely than the control group to trust the pediatrician's diagnosis. In contrast, parents who'd seen information on Kawasaki disease were more skeptical. Only 61 percent of parents in the Kawasaki group trusted the doctor's diagnosis -- versus 81 percent of parents in the control group. Almost 91 percent of parents in the scarlet fever group trusted the doctor's conclusion, the findings showed. Scarlet fever and Kawasaki disease do share certain symptoms -- namely, rash and fever. But they are very different conditions, Milanaik explained. Scarlet fever is a bacterial infection that requires antibiotics. Without treatment, scarlet fever can sometimes lead to serious complications, including heart damage. Kawasaki disease involves inflammation in blood vessels throughout the body. Doctors treat it with anti-inflammatory drugs -- both to ease the symptoms and to prevent damage to the heart. It's easy to see how parents presented with a description of Kawasaki disease would doubt a doctor's diagnosis of scarlet fever, according to Milanaik. Similarly, she said, any time parents Google a "collection of symptoms," they could turn up a confusing array of possibilities. So, Milanaik said, it's important for parents to ask their doctor about any online information they dig up. "Don't be afraid to do that," she urged. "I'd always rather have patients ask questions." Dr. Jefry Biehler, a pediatrician who wasn't involved in the study, agreed. "As doctors, we should welcome those questions," said Biehler, who heads pediatrics at Nicklaus Children's Hospital in Miami. "Actually," he added, "we're often happy to have this [online] information brought to our attention -- whether it's good or bad -- so we're aware of what's out there." But while parents should ideally ask questions, Milanaik said, it's just as important for doctors to be proactive. It's helpful, she said, if pediatricians explain their "thought process" behind a diagnosis, so parents have a clearer understanding for "why it's this, and not that." Doctors can also offer suggestions for trustworthy health-related websites, Milanaik said. Biehler agreed, and said many pediatricians do try to steer parents toward "reliable" sources, such as the websites of the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and the American Academy of Pediatrics. "We should also be asking parents if they need any more information, or clarification, from us," Biehler said. The study presented parents with a hypothetical situation, and didn't ask them about their actual online habits or trust in their own pediatrician, Milanaik acknowledged. But the study design, she said, allowed a more objective look at how online health information can sway people's thinking. Milanaik was scheduled to present the findings Thursday at the annual meeting of the Pediatric Academic Societies, in San Francisco. Findings presented at meetings are generally viewed as preliminary until they've been published in a peer-reviewed journal. More information The U.S. National Library of Medicine has advice on finding reliable health information. Copyright ¬© 2017 HealthDay. All rights reserved. (NYSE: KODK) for Gannett Newspapers in the mid-1990s, the once-venerable photo giant was going through a restructuring that, at the time, would yield big profits for stockholders. Kodak broke up and auctioned off its Sterling Winthrop pharmaceutical company and, in 1993, spun off its Eastman Chemical Co. (NYSE: EMN) unit to shareholders.
